stem: A client who underwent a right tibia ORIF (open reduction internal fixation) 2 days ago reports increasing pain in the right lower leg that is unrelieved by opioid analgesics. Which of the following actions should the nurse take FIRST?

rationale.correct: Compartment syndrome is a limb-threatening and potentially life-threatening condition. The priority is to assess circulation, pulses, sensation, and movement in the affected limb to determine the extent of the compartment syndrome and risk to the patient. Elevating the extremity is contraindicated, as it can decrease arterial perfusion and worsen the condition. Early intervention is crucial to prevent permanent damage.
rationale.incorrect: Administering another dose of opioid analgesic may mask the symptoms of compartment syndrome and delay definitive treatment. Elevating the extremity is contraindicated in compartment syndrome, as it can further reduce arterial blood flow to the affected limb. Notifying the provider is essential, but assessing the client first provides the provider with vital information about the severity of the condition.
clinicalPearls: Unrelieved pain is a hallmark sign of compartment syndrome.
The 6 P's of compartment syndrome are pain, pallor, paresthesia, paralysis, pulselessness, and poikilothermia.
Compartment syndrome can lead to permanent muscle and nerve damage if not treated promptly.

questionTrap.trap: Students may choose pain medication administration because the patient is reporting pain. This distracts from the underlying cause.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always consider the etiology of the pain, especially in post-operative patients. Unrelieved pain is a red flag.

mnemonic.title: 6 P's
mnemonic.expansion: Pain, Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia

reviewUnits.title: Compartment Syndrome
reviewUnits.content: Compartment syndrome is a condition in which increased pressure within a limited space compromises the circulation and function of the tissues within that space.

itemContext.sbar: 0700: Nurse Smith reporting on Jane Doe, DOB 03/08/1962. Post-op day 2, right tibia ORIF. Patient reports increasing pain in right lower leg, rated 8/10, unrelieved by morphine 4mg IV. 0705: Pedal pulses are present but diminished compared to the left leg. 0710: Toes are cool to the touch. Capillary refill is approximately 4 seconds. 0715: Patient reports numbness and tingling in the right foot. Neurovascular checks were normal immediately post-op. 0720: Patient is alert and oriented x3. Vital signs stable. 0725: Requesting evaluation for possible compartment syndrome. Patient is on standard precautions.

options.text: Assess circulation, pulses, sensation, and movement in the affected extremity.
Administer another dose of opioid analgesic as prescribed.
Elevate the affected extremity on pillows above heart level.
Notify the health care provider immediately.
